h2.div: 2020 Annual Budget Vote and Election Postponed

p.style: text-align: left;

div.p: Notice is hereby given that the annual Meeting and Budget Vote scheduled for Tuesday, May 19th is hereby postponed until at least June 1, 2020, and the circulation, filing, and collection of petitions for Board of Education positions are postponed pursuant to the New York State Governor's Executive Order 202.13. Further notice will be given when more information is available.

h2.div: April 24, 2020 - Re: Middle and high school grading during remote learning

p.style: text-align: center;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans;
span.strong: RE: MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL GRADING DURING REMOTE LEARNING

div.p: Final numeric course grades will be based upon numeric grades in quarters 1-3. Numeric grades for quarter 3 are those in place as of March 13th with adjustments as teacher determined for previously announced assignments due at a later date. Summative (final) grades during the period of Remote Learning (presumably the 4th quarter) are P/F. In instances where the numeric grade on March 13th is below passing, students may earn a passing numeric grade (65 or above) for the course as a result of their passing work during Remote Learning.
Teachers may use qualitative and/or quantitative feedback (grading) for student work during Remote Learning.

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue;touchstart:p6p2H; touchmove:FwuNnf; touchend:yfqBxc(preventMouseEvents=true|preventDefault=true); touchcancel:JMtRjd;focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue;touchstart:p6p2H; touchmove:FwuNnf; touchend:yfqBxc(preventMouseEvents=true|preventDefault=true); touchcancel:JMtRjd;focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.p: Dear New Paltz Parents and Guardians,

p.style: text-align: center;

div.p: On “Grading” During “Remote Learning”

p.style: text-align: center;

div.p: I expect that few will recall “Welcome Back Kotter,” the 1970’s TV comedy series set in a fictional Brooklyn High School. Its principal, Dr. Woodman, wrote his dissertation on “attendance.”

Similarly, I majored in “grades” – both personally and professionally. My parents taught me very early that “grades” meant much to them. I gave them many reasons to remind me that I “wasn’t getting it.” Later, my career as a teacher and administrator immersed me in “grading” --- as an unavoidable feature of schooling and as a repeated focus of family anxiety. I learned much about why that anxiety is exaggerated -- even though my daughter would be the first to ask why I was so much like my parents.

I say to this -- to students, parents and even teachers – to emphasize the following: this is not a time to worry about school grades. In this pandemical moment of bricks and mortar school closure, the District’s approach to Remote Learning aims to safeguard students. That’s very different from grading them. Nor is it necessary to trade one for the other.
At its April 1st meeting, the New Paltz BOE approved the following resolution:

p.style: margin-left: 0; padding-left: 0; text-indent: 20px;
p.em: During the period of school closure, teachers may respond to student work qualitatively (through descriptive language) and/or quantitatively (numerically.) Any needed summary of individual student standing will be done on a Pass/Fail basis.

div.p: This resolution is consistent with the Remote Learning Plan that New Paltz teachers and administrators first implemented on March 30th. That Plan includes the following statement:

p.style: margin-left: 0; padding-left: 0; text-indent: 20px;
p.em: Emotional wellbeing -- for ourselves, our students, and our families --- comes first. Everything else, subject matter included, is second. Teaching is relationship-centered and emotion is the power that drives learning. In the present crisis, it is all the more necessary that we keep our students’ social and emotional development strongly in mind.

div.p: I wrote the following in my April 6th community letter:

p.style: margin-left: 0; padding-left: 0; text-indent: 20px;

div.p: [Some view] … schooling as a measured race to be run: students are encouraged to “keep pace,” “not fall behind” and if at all possible “to get out ahead.” If schooling was ever that way, it cannot be so now. [Instead] we are asking our teachers to … to connect with kids where they are, to support their mental, social and physical health, as well as their continued academic and developmental growth.
On April 16th, Dr. Mario Fernandez, NPHS principal, notified students and parents that:

p.style: margin-left: 0; padding-left: 0; text-indent: 20px;
p.em: … grades as of March 13, 2020 will stand as the numeric course grades for transcripts and ranking purposes. Students with failing course grades as of March 13, 2020 may pass those courses through their subsequent Remote Learning efforts

div.p: Applicable also to middle school students, his comments reflect the judgment of District and building administrators about how best to modify grading policy to

p.style: margin-left: 0; padding-left: 0; text-indent: 0;

li.p: Encourage those students who need a lift to gain course credit; and

p.style: margin-left: 0; padding-left: 0; text-indent: 0;

li.p: Settle questions about class ranking and transcripts.

div.p: Through what we’ve experienced so far, the foremost concern of New Paltz teachers and administrators is to meet our duty of care to all of our students. It will continue to be our foremost concern as we move forward.
Sincerely,
Bernard Josefsberg

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Dear New Paltz Parents and Guardians,

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: As per the Governor’s most recent Executive Order (see below), our school closure has been extended to May 15

sup.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 10.799999999999999px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: . Even as we anticipated this extension, we all await that future moment when the schools can re-open. At

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: underline; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: this

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: moment, I want to thank everyone – parents, faculty, and staff – for their continued care of the children of this community.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: B. Josefsberg

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Interim Superintendent

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;
margin-left: 48px; margin-right: 48px; padding-left: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0; white-space: normal;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;
span.em: Amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, Governor Andrew M. Cuomo today announced all NYS on Pause restrictions and closures will be extended until May 15th. This action is taken in consultation with other regional states. The states will re-evaluate after this additional closure period. Governor Cuomo also directed all New Yorkers to wear masks or face coverings on public transportation systems and while taking private transportation or riding in for-hire vehicles. Additionally, all operators of public systems, private carriers and for-hire vehicles must wear a mask or face covering at all times while working. These directives expand on the Executive Order

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: underline; vertical-align: baseline;
font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;
span.em: by the Governor yesterday requiring all people in New York to wear a mask or a face covering when out in public and in situations where social distancing cannot be maintained. The Executive Order will go into effect on Friday, April 17th, at 8 PM.

p.style: margin-left: 48px; margin-right: 48px; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: underline; vertical-align: baseline;

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue;touchstart:p6p2H; touchmove:FwuNnf; touchend:yfqBxc(preventMouseEvents=true|preventDefault=true); touchcancel:JMtRjd;focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.p: Dear New Paltz Parents and Guardians,

Face to face schooling has been shut down for less than a month. It seems an era ago. I hope that you and your family are keeping healthy and adjusting as well as possible. Today, the New York Board of Regents cancelled Regents Examinations for this year. Additionally, the Governor extended his school closure order to April 29th.
Teachers are in the second week of enacting the District’s Remote Learning Plan. As I told the BOE during its remote BOE meeting last week:

p.em: I’ve been told often that teachers are the strength of this District. Our Remote Learning Plan sought to provide sufficient structure while at the same time relying upon individual teacher initiative. We encouraged teachers to work in teams – grade level teams, subject area teams, support services teams, mental health teams and so forth. In combination with the different learning experiences that are built into the K-12 continuum, our approach can be expected to result in much more variation than occurs in a brick and mortar setting. This might be a concern to some who understand schooling as a uniformly measured race to be run: students are encouraged to “keep pace,” “not fall behind” and if at all possible “to get out ahead.” If schooling was ever that way, it cannot be so now. We are asking our teachers to use our available means to connect with kids where they are and support their mental, social and physical health, as well as their continued academic and developmental growth. We anticipate that parents will continue to ask questions and express their concerns. They should do so first to their students’ teachers; then to their principals; and then to the superintendent. We expect to use that feedback and improve our Remote Learning Plan as might be required.

div.p: April 7th is designated a Superintendent’s Conference Day. Teachers will focus upon mastering new virtual platforms and otherwise upgrading their remote learning strategies.

Lastly, the Governor has postponed school budget elections to early June. State level revenue shortfalls will most likely reduce local school district aid for the 2020-21 academic year. We do not yet know the extent of any such reduction. However, since approximately 25% of our annual budget depends upon state funds, we are in the process of reviewing previously proposed expenditures for next year and presenting the BOE with some options for revising last month’s proposal.
Please take care of yourselves.
Sincerely,
Bernard Josefsberg

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue;touchstart:p6p2H; touchmove:FwuNnf; touchend:yfqBxc(preventMouseEvents=true|preventDefault=true); touchcancel:JMtRjd;focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.p: Dear Parents and Guardians:

We are all continuing to come to grips with what is the ‘new normal.’ All of us find ourselves tuning into ever-changing health advisories and expectations while balancing concerns for our loved ones. We are deeply missing our students and find ourselves returning to their welfare, time and again. It is a difficult time to prioritize educational standards, while we know some families are without work and dealing with food insecurities, meanwhile mental health challenges are commonplace across the nation. The entire District is working to assist families in one of the greatest modern challenges many of us have experienced; we urge you to seek out resources if your family is in need. https://sites.google.com/newpaltz.k12.ny.us/distancelearning/mental-health-resources

On Friday, Governor Cuomo extended the mandatory closing of all New York schools through April 15th. We have established a remote learning community to facilitate and maintain the education of your child, beginning Monday, March 30th. Teachers will be establishing guidelines and connecting with students at that time. To learn more about the remote learning opportunities for each building, please contact your principal or visit https://sites.google.com/newpaltz.k12.ny.us/distancelearning/distance-learning-resources

Teachers have been advised to keep all children’s social and emotional needs at the forefront of their instruction. Our school social workers, psychologists and school counselors are available through email to communicate, support and refer as needed. Their contact information is found on each building’s web page.

If your household requires a laptop device to maintain educational connections to their teachers, and you have not been in contact with our Technology Department, please reach out to your building principal.

Health officials have advised us of the importance of establishing a routine during the ‘new normal’ and we hope to inculcate some of this Monday. By working together, we can help New Paltz children regain connections to peers, teachers, and meaningful learning. If your family is in need, do not hesitate to reach out to us for assistance and support.
We will continue to reach out with updates in the days ahead. Be well.
New Paltz Administrative Team

h2.div: March 27, 2020 - Message from the NPCSD Board of Education

div.jsaction: click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue;touchstart:p6p2H; touchmove:FwuNnf; touchend:yfqBxc(preventMouseEvents=true|preventDefault=true); touchcancel:JMtRjd;focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

click:cOuCgd; mousedown:UX7yZ; mouseup:lbsD7e; mouseenter:tfO1Yc; mouseleave:JywGue;touchstart:p6p2H; touchmove:FwuNnf; touchend:yfqBxc(preventMouseEvents=true|preventDefault=true); touchcancel:JMtRjd;focus:AHmuwe; blur:O22p3e; contextmenu:mg9Pef;

div.p: We are reaching out to you during this unprecedented time in our school district and community to acknowledge the turbulent impact the Coronavirus (COVID-19) is having on our district, families, students, and community at large. The Board of Education recognizes how diligently the employees of the New Paltz Central School District have been working, in conjunction with local, county and state officials to adapt and stay true to our commitment to support students and families academically, socially and emotionally. Much of this work is being done behind the scenes, but is very much admired and appreciated. The New Paltz Central School District Board of Education is confident that decisions being made represent the best course of action for our school district, its staff, students and our families. We appreciate the toll these extreme changes exert on families, especially those parents who are essential workers or those who are transitioning to working remotely.

The Search for a new Superintendent of Schools. The Board of Education is adhering to our initial search timeline by pivoting and adapting to a remote process. We will keep the community apprised as we continue to move forward.

The upcoming Budget and BOE Election. The Board of Education, in partnership with Interim Superintendent Dr. Bernard Josefsberg, has been keeping up-to-date on the ever-evolving state of affairs in regards to New York State budget matters and how they pertain to school funding and programming. As things continue to change, we want to assure the community that we are at the forefront of the issues that impact our district community and students. By executive order the Governor has changed the original May 19, 2020 date of the budget vote and BOE election to at least June 1, 2020.

Communication. The BOE is commited to balancing an open meeting schedule with the need to practice diligent social distancing. As many districts have, we are preparing to livestream video conferences of BOE meetings; we will be recording such meetings for later viewings for the public. We will share these details as they develop.

Please join us in support of Interim Superintendent Bernard Josefsberg, our District Administration and faculty who have collaborated with care and expertise to prepare our District Remote Learning Plan - an approach that puts children and their learning first. We would also like to thank our New Paltz Central School District community for their tireless efforts in food distribution, outreach, programming efforts, etc. Please know there has been an outpouring of concern and commitment on the part of the staff, teachers, administrators and others to do whatever is necessary during this most difficult time. We owe a deep debt of gratitude to the essential workers throughout our community: first responders, grocery, custodial/sanitation, postal workers and many more who must go out as many of us stay in. We are also deeply appreciative of the incredible efforts of Transportation Director Maureen Ryan and Food Services Director Mike Robinson and their staff who have been ensuring and will continue to ensure the needs for school meals are being met.

Lastly, we want to reassure you and your families that you are not alone. The New Paltz Central School District is with you during this unprecedented time. We hope to welcome everyone back to our schools as soon as possible.
Stay safe, healthy and well.
Best regards,
Michael O’Donnell, President
Glenn LaPolt, Vice-President
Diana Armstead, Trustee
Dominick Profaci, Trustee
Sophia Skiles, Trustee
Bianca Tanis, Trustee
Teresa Thompson, Trustee

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Dear Parents and Guardians;

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: As ordered by Governor Cuomo on March 27, 2020:

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;
span.em: ... All schools shall remain closed until April 15, 2020, at which time the continued closure shall be re-evaluated. No school shall be subject to a diminution in school aid due to failure to meet the 180 day in session requirement as a result of the COVID-19 outbreak, provided their closure does not extend beyond the term set forth herein. School districts must continue plans for alternative instructional options, distribution and availability of meals, and child care, with an emphasis on serving children of essential workers, and continue to first use any vacation and snow days remaining.

div.p: Dear New Paltz Families,

We hope that you and yours are doing well. As the evolution of COVID-19 continues to progress at a rapid rate, we are undoubtedly all facing very stressful times and interruptions to so many aspects of our daily lives.

The emotional wellbeing of our students and families is our first priority. Everything else, subject matter included, is second. Nonetheless, familiar principles anchor how we will begin to adapt a continuing academic program to this unprecedented time of social and personal stress. As this process emerges, we will continuously collect feedback from our stakeholders about our successes and areas of growth to refine our work. Our intention is not to overwhelm but rather provide resources, learning opportunities, and support as needed.

If teachers have not already done so, they will begin to reach out to your child on Monday, March 30th via phone, email, or teacher websites. Your child may already know how to navigate these avenues of communication while other students may need additional guidance. We ask that you assist your child to the greatest extent possible utilizing the communication avenues to contact your child’s teacher. Along with the resources noted earlier, Google Classroom and/or Google Meet may be additional avenues for teachers to connect to your children.

Modifying teaching practices in such a radically different way with virtually no notice is a huge task. The collegiality and collaboration we are seeing throughout the community is impressive. We are facing an incredibly challenging situation and we are asking a lot of students, parents and teachers. We also know that everyone is doing their very best to make this a successful experience for all. We appreciate your patience and understanding as a necessary part of the process.
Thank you.
Mr. Ross Hogan, Duzine Elementary
Mr. Sean Inglee, Lenape Elementary
Mrs. Ann Sheldon, New Paltz Middle School
Dr. Mario Fernandez, New Paltz High School

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Dear Parents and Guardians;

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: New Paltz School District has been active in the past days determining how to best assist our students and families during the Pandemic of Covid-19. We understand this changing landscape has created significant upheaval in everyone’s lives. We are actively working to meet families concerns and the rapidly changing State and Federal requirements.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Per the Governor’s most recent Executive Order, our schools will remain closed through April 1st. The District recently designated March 23rd - 27th as “Spring Break.” Overarching these official acts is the expectation that school closures will be extended.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: In the upcoming days we will be announcing several initiatives to support students academically, socially, and emotionally. A District Remote Learning Plan will begin on March 30th. We will be presenting information specific to each building, as well as, community resources which families may find helpful.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Your building administrators will be guiding teachers and students in this endeavor. Ultimately we all must work together to facilitate student’s access to education and connections during unprecedented times of social distancing.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: We are gathering information on the needs of our community regarding internet connectivity and the availability of devices at home. Complete this survey ONLY if you have no device (other than a cell phone) and/or no internet connection in your household:

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: underline; vertical-align: baseline;
font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: . This form will also be made available to families participating in our food home delivery program.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: In the meantime, please look forward to information on your child resuming their access to education in a format that will vary building to building. Similar information is forthcoming for students who receive mandated services through Special Education, Section 504 programming, or school counseling services from social workers and psychologists. This is a particularly troubling time for many of us. We urge families to seek out the resources listed at the end of this letter and those on our website.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: In the meantime stay healthy and safe.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: More to follow,

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: NPCSD Administrative Team

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Dear New Paltz Parents and Guardians:

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: On March 10th – when the prospect of a school closure changed from a possibility to a certainty -- I sent a memo to all New Paltz teachers. I wrote:

p.style: margin-left: 31px; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;
span.em: I am broaching the question of what can be done --- given our human and technological resources -- to “maintain continuity of operations” in the event of school closures aimed a mitigating viral spread.

p.style: margin-left: 31px; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;
span.em: The details of “What can be done?” will depend on several factors including closure length, grade level, content area, and access to digital platforms. Nonetheless, I anticipate that events will require that we immediately engage some general questions such as:

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;
span.em: How might K-5 teachers “keep learning alive” during a school closure through prescribed activities and experiences that nurture student curiosity, imagination and developmental growth?

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;
span.em: How might 6-12 teachers -- across the respective content areas --- “preload” subject- relevant assignments, projects, and explorations that maintain students on their paths toward graduation?

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: When we closed our schools on March 13th, we lost the face-to-face interaction between teachers and students that

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: underline; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: was

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: our foremost “platform” for creating learning. We

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: underline; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: did not

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: have available a ready-built, equally powerful alternative that could support the daily routines and methods upon which we relied.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: That aside, “though much is taken, much abides” -- or more directly, there’s no use worrying about what we can’t do. Now we must be imaginative about what we can do to keep kids connected to learning.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Four days after closure, we are at the beginning of what will no doubt be an uneven, non-uniform process. Certain teachers at various grade levels are more accustomed than others in using remote learning technology to keep their students “on track.” Realistic expectations need to be developed and disseminated to all teachers to guide their practice in the coming weeks. Certain students need to be equipped to access the technology that is readily available to their peers. New webpages need to be designed that will link families to web-based resources. Those resources need to be identified and vetted. These are only some of the considerations that we are weaving together.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Behind the scene of what individual teachers already may be doing on their own initiative, we are using this time to create shared, alternative means of “keeping learning alive.” You soon can expect to see the results of that work.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Sincerely,

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Bernard Josefsberg

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Dear New Paltz Parents and Guardians,

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: At the direction of the Ulster County Executive, our schools are closed for the next two weeks. It is possible that the closure will last longer, implicating various New York State Education Department requirements. Among those is the 180 day minimum school year requirement.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: We have been advised that school districts may seek a waiver of that requirement under certain conditions. One such condition obliges districts to exhaust any available emergency and vacation days before a waiver will be entertained.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Accordingly and as odd as it may seem to break during a closure, we are changing the date of spring break, now scheduled for April 6- April 10th. Instead that break will be scheduled to begin on March 23rd and end on the 27th .

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Again, we are doing so to best position the District to respond to state education requirements. This change will not affect essential food services.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: These will continue.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Sincerely,

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Bernard Josefsberg

div.jsaction: touchstart:UrsOsc; click:KjsqPd; focusout:QZoaZ; mouseover:y0pDld; mouseout:dq0hvd;fv1Rjc:jbFSOd;CrfLRd:SzACGe;

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: We know that a prolonged school closure creates a tremendous burden on many families. The New Paltz Central School District will begin distributing food to families in need on Tuesday, March 17th. Breakfast and lunch will be available for delivery daily. If you would like to receive breakfast and lunch, please call (845) 256-4050 or click on this link:

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;
font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: and specify the number of children under the age of 18, your physical address (for food delivery) and the best way to contact you. More details will be forthcoming.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: In addition, NPCSD administrators, Board of Education Members, local elected officials, PTA leadership, local non-profits, and New Paltz United Teachers are working together to support all families and students during these uncertain times. Community members will be conducting a food drive for child-friendly, non-perishable food items to support ALL families and community members in need of support. Beginning on Monday, non-perishable, individually packaged food items can be donated between the hours of 10am and 3pm at the New Paltz Middle School front parking lot (facing Main Street).

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: You can also contribute to the The NPMS PTA CheddarUp fundraiser,

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;
font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: . Your donations will go to supporting families facing increased food insecurity due to the impact of COVID-19. Please see the list of needed donations.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: easy mac and cheese - add water only

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Dear New Paltz Parents and Guardians,

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Several days ago, I referred to coordination and shared judgment as the basis for any decision about keeping school doors open or closed. Area school district superintendents conferred today following the closure of the Wallkill CSD schools. We were advised of the County Executive’s guidance that it would be premature for other districts to close in response. We accepted that guidance and are remaining open.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: At the same time, County health officials are discouraging event organizers from moving forward with indoor events larger than 100 people. Accordingly, tomorrow evening’s Scholarship Concert in the High School auditorium has been postponed. Please be assured that I will continue to keep you informed as events unfold.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Sincerely,

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Bernard Josefsberg

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: March 8, 2020

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Dear New Paltz Parents and Guardians,

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: As anticipated, Coronavirus concerns deepen and now include a positive test result in Ulster County.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Focusing specifically on the welfare of all students and adults in the New Paltz schools, I want to emphasize how swiftly state, county, and local officials have assembled to create a coordinated response to mitigate viral spread.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Using all available communication channels, all New Paltz agencies are connected with each other and to county and state officials.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: This coordination means that any prospective decision about keeping schools open or briefly closing them for cleaning purposes will reflect shared judgment, known facts, and appropriate caution.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Shared judgment, known facts, and appropriate caution will continue to guide our decision-making as we move forward.

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Sincerely,

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Bernard Josefsberg

p.style: margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 0; text-align: left; text-indent: 0;

span.style: font-family: Open Sans; font-size: 18px; font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; text-decoration: normal; vertical-align: baseline;

p.span: Interim Superintendent
